prime.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Smoking is the prime cause of lung disease.
Our prime concern is providing jobs for all young school leavers.
He was named as the prime suspect in the murder investigation.
Good management is of prime importance in business.
prime.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: of the very best quality or kind
prime.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: The hotel is in a prime location overlooking the valley.
prime.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: the time in your life when you are strongest and most active
prime.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: He is now past his prime.
a man in the prime of life
a young singer who was tragically cut off in her prime (=died while she was in her prime)
She’s now 40 and still in her prime.
prime.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: to prepare someone for a situation so that they know what to do
prime.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: Did you prime her with what to say?
He had a shower and primed himself for action.
He had been primed to say nothing about it.
prime.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: to prepare a gun or bomb so that it can fire or explode
prime.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: to put a special layer of paint on a surface, in order to prepare it for the next layer
prime.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: All metal surfaces will have to be primed.
prime.translation[2].definitions[3].defi: to pour water into a water pump in order to make it ready to work
prime.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: acres of prime real estate right by an international airport
prime.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: The developer’s prime objective is to build houses at maximum profit, with minimum care for the environment.
their prime concern was for the safety of the international financial system.
Martin Marietta Corp., the prime contractor in the rocket-engine development program
prime.translation[4].definitions[0].defi: to make the economy grow faster by increasing government spending, hoping that this will encourage business to invest more
prime.translation[4].definitions[0].exam: Direct investments in job creation are essential to prime the pump and get the economy up and running again.
prime.translation[5].definitions[0].defi: used to talk about how much higher an interest rate is than the PRIME RATE (=the interest rate charged by banks to their best borrowers)
prime.translation[5].definitions[0].exam: The working-capital loan carried an interest rate of 3½ points above prime.
